intro: Sticherus quadripartitus, commonly known as the four-parted sticherus, is a small, annual herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, commonly known as the buckwheat family, and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters, with a basal rosette of leaves and erect flowering stems. Its flowers are usually greenish or reddish, and it produces small, dry fruits called achenes. The species is adapted to survive in harsh environments, with mechanisms to conserve water and withstand high temperatures.
